page.title: 14PARISH OF TIBBERMORE (7)
page.content: The farmer told us that during the last war, sixty acres of the farm were taken over by the R.A.F., who built a small fighter station there. Also on the farmland are two sand and gravel pits which provide material for road improvement schemes in the immediate area. We spoke to a retired headmaster of Tibbermore Primary School, and we asked him if he could tell us what the name "Tibbermore" is derived from. He told us that the Gaelic word for a well is "Tober" and the word "Muir" in Gaelic is Mary, so the meaning could possibly be St. Mary's Well. He told us when he was in the school about twenty five years ago that he had around fifty pupils. There was also a post office, which not only sold a wide variety of goods, but also acted as an unofficial Community Centre!
